dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very English scene - a beautiful English garden belongi mansion house. A smartly turned out gardener in green ove is raking leaves. It's an impressive picture of Britishne order. Another gardener, DAVE is trimming the edge of the We see shots of the garden; plants, trees, a gazebo, sund water fountain etc. We follow one of the gardeners pushin wheelbarrow across the width of the lawn and we see the r this impressive property. Title: 'PAPADOPOULOS & SONS'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS PARRINGTON knocks on a bedroom door. The door opens o PAPADOPOULOS in his bedroom doing up his shirt in a mirro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chauffeur-driven Mercedes pulls up to the front of the house. MRS PARRINGTON, the housekeeper and nanny, waits f car. HARRY and his children, JAMES, KATIE and THEO exit t the front door. As they do so, MRS PARRINGTON makes sure children are smartly turned out. The chauffeur gets out a opens the door for the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the car make its way through London and images of City, the Gherkin, NatWest Tower, Canary Wharf. The Merce pulls up outside a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRESENTER is standing behind a lectern, with a large cr vase award. Behind him, on the stage, we see a 'European Entrepreneur of the Year Award' banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orphaned when he was just a boy, Harry Papadopoulos came to this country with nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We cut to the family seated at a round table. The childre bored. HARRY listens proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry was a grafter, entering the restaurant trade as a young man. (Beat) That's a euphemism for 'Greek waiter' isn't it? There is some laughter in the audience. We cut to HARRY a who attempts to smile off the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only joking Harry. He then started the now famous Papadopoulos & Sons - doing all things Greek. From taramasalata to olive oil and frozen mousakas - which, I must admit, my wife and I are partial to occasionally. Not one to settle, Harry's made the move into commercial property where he's about to embark on one of the most audacious developments yet - Papadopoulos Plaza. A two million square foot redevelopment in the heart of our great city. (Applause from the audience) Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you European Entrepreneur of the Year. Harry Papadopoulos. Awards music. We now cut to HARRY getting up from the tab momentarily acknowledges the applause. The children are c politely but absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the photo call for 'European Entrepreneur of the Yea PHOTOGRAPHER is taking shots of HARRY holding his award. JAMES and THEO stand alongside their father. The children disinterested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's lovely. (Referring to the vase) Now just hold it up a bit for me. Yeah, that's nice. Bunch up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bit more. Perfect. Now touch the vase for me, if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch it? What a perv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a stammer) Katie. You're the p... p... perv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're the f.. f.. freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on guys. Big smiles. Big smiles for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really work in a restaurant Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time ago. Touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys. This is supposed to be a celebration. What's the Greek word? Is it Opa? Opa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch the vase. The family touch the vase and force a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS PARRINGTON is drying dishes. HARRY, THEO, KATIE and J are at the table having supper. THEO is on a laptop, chec stock market trends. KATIE is texting. HARRY is reading congratulatory cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations from the Prime Minister. Sir Derek Otterly was there today Mrs Parrington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Derek? You must remember him. He's been to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because they're all so dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird. Gold doing well. Tech stocks down. DAVE enters and hands MRS PARRINGTON some empty mugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice one Mrs P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks Dave. Would you like to stay for some supper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Best not. Got some dinner at home. That's a nice vase, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: European Entrepreneur of the Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave. Did you g.. g.. get my cuttings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did mate. It's in the greenhouse. I got you a Caryopteris and a Philadelphus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers man. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow. Dave exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy? What did Papadopoulos & Sons borrow for the property development?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About three hundred million. MRS PARRINGTON shuts and removes THEO's laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the trials and tribulations of the stock market. Finish your supper young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nanny P!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat up or there'll be no pudding. I've made you a nice sponge. THEO pulls a childish grimace and starts to breath heavil through his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, Four, Eight, 16...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty two, sixty four, 128..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something is happening with interbank lending Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. We'll talk about it tomorrow. HARRY gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be a long summer. HARRY exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking them to a business awards ceremony is hardly a family day out. My suggestion was a cottage in Lyme Regis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE is at the front door in the hallway. He is putting o his muddy boots. HARRY enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave? I need to talk to you about James. It's... Look, you really should be doing that at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Its. He needs to complete his degree. And this gardening, the horticulture, the plants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a huge distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just helping him out during the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I need him to complete his studies and you're diverting his attention. And frankly, it's not what I pay you for. Dave doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't be so churlish. You know, if you were worked for my company you'd probably be fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight Mr. Papadopoulos. DAVE exits. JAMES comes through the hallway. He has overh some of the conversation and he's upset. He walks past HA flashes him a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. JAMES now stops and returns to say something to his fathe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wa... wa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down. He stops. He takes a couple of deep breaths and composes himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wa.. wa..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to learn how to... You really need to learn how to express yourself more calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanker. (Beat) Wanker. JAMES exits up the staircase. HARRY watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY taps on JAMES' door. There is no answer. He walks i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James? Can I come in? JAMES' room resembles a botanical garden. JAMES is at his with pots of plants and various tools and test tubes with and desk lamps. JAMES looks through a microscope, studyin leaf, ignoring his father. HARRY surveys the room trying accommodate his son's interest in botany. He notices a po Charles Darwin with a quote. He reads it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not the strongest to survive, nor the most intelligent but those adaptable to change. Fascinating. Charles Darwin. (Latching onto a random plant) Ah. Look at that. (Beat) And that's... JAMES answers without looking up from the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know, that the average garden contains over three and a half million species?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. I'm not going back to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's only a year and then you've got a law degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no intention of running P.. P.. Papadopoulos & Sons. I can't even pronounce it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Finish your studies. The plants. It's a hobby. Sure. Give yourself options. You may change your mind about the business. You know, there are a lot of creative roles now in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like marketing. Alright. Defer the final year. Take a year out, why not? Fine. But don't quit. Your mother would have said the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your mother would probably have said do what you feel was right but I'd argue she was wrong. And then we'd argue. Probably. And she'd win. That was your mother. At least consider deferring. JAMES thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll consider deferring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Great. Great. So, there you are, it's not a definitely not? HARRY wants to bond but doesn't know where to start. HARR latches onto an English Ivy in a Union Jack plant pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this one called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an ivy. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs P!(Pause, waits for a response) Mrs P! Look, I'd better. HARRY goes to exit and then comes back to shake his son's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Well done. For. You know. HARRY heads towards the door and just before he exits he an emphatic double thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY opens the front door. We see a friendly door-to-doo salesman with a charity badge around his neck. He has a p basket of cleaning products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening boss. Sorry to disturb. I work for a homeless charity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New dish cloths?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you people operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a badge. HARRY studies the badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mention of a charity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on boss. Give us a break. I'm trying to earn a living here. Look. Got tea towels, surface cleaners, scrubbers, brushes, window sprays, shammies - for drying the car. Cars. THEO appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy. You need to see the news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there mini boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a... he's a... he. He works for a charity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a cake sale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cakes? Did you say cakes? Did he say cakes? How do you know? That's what I want to do. Open up a cake shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cakes? Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cup cakes, individually decorated gingerbread men, bite-sized apple strudels, gooey fudge balls, mini- muffins as well as your traditional fare. Got a business plan and everything. It'll be egalitarian but feel exclusive - sort of my mission statement really. The Progressive People's Cake Shop. With... progressive pricing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very good. I know a thing or two about the food business as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I'm looking for investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retail's not for me, I'm afraid. Staff. Nightmare. They'll nick your cakes, upset your customers, then do you for wrongful dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks for the encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's buy something. The news Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how much for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever. How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shammy. It's a shammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to say that word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's a silly word and I don't know what it's for and I don't know if you're genuine. And I'll probably never use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY walks in with the entire box of cleaning products a hands them to MRS PARRINGTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. A shammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come look Daddy. On the TV, we see a 'New Bank Crisis?' banner and a repor standing outside a bank in the city of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it up. THEO points the remote and turns up the volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic confusion and chaos. They said it couldn't happen again but today it just did sending shock waves through the world's markets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another bank collapse. The TV images cut to people leaving an office with boxes their belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All 8,000 members of staff have been asked to leave while the bank is put into liquidation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes as a shock but not a surprise. HARRY's mobile phone rings. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas. I'm watching now. It's insane. I don't know. Why don't you call them? Alright. I'll see you first thing tomorrow. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will this have repercussions on your loan? Harry is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very good word Theo. Isn't it? Daddy? Repercussions. (Beat) It's a good word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Sorry. Yes. It's a very good word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12   EXT. PAPADOPOULOS & SONS FACTORY. DAY 2. Next morning. Establishing shot. We are at the Papadopoul Sons HQ - the exterior of the factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13   INT. PAPADOPOULOS & SONS FACTORY OFFICE. DAY 2. HARRY, FAT LAKI and NICHOLAS are walking into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've revalued the property. They're calling in the guarantees. You need to find thirty mil now. Six months to find the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if we don't? What happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll put you and everything you own into administration. Harry. You took out crazy loans. Our business is making feta cheese for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gambled it on a shopping mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could do without these comments right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the finance director of this company Harry. You never listened. Never. It always had to be bigger, better. Like these offices. We didn't need these offices. Do you know how much we paid for that 'work of art ' up there? Do you? Two hundred grand. For a fish. Nicholas points towards a fish hung across the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do Nick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our business was profitable Harry. I was going to retire in two years. I'd like to bring that forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're resigning? Now? The accountants coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Harry. En boro. En boro. NICHOLAS exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough. That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas. Can you believe that? ROB and SOPHIE, an American, enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, fan and hitting? Hey! Fat Laki! You know why they call this guy Fat Laki? SOPHIE shrugs. FAT LAKI indicates how big he once was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stopped eating bread. It's sad though. I loved bread. But. What can you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sophie. Just relocated from our New York office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Really pleased to meet you. Can I just say, I'm a huge fan of Greek food. Especially the cakes. I love Baklava.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. The ship's going down and we've got baklava.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it the banks are pulling the rug? What are the bastards proposing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've demanded the 300 million we borrowed. Thirty by close of play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet mother of God. They are sons of bitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've taken a new position on the value of the property development. It's triggered the guarantees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you sell it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even a building site yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, its bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put something offshore, I said. He wanted to pay his taxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should have been more Greek about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. It's bankruptcy baby. Not disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accountants. When it's good, they get paid. When it's bad, they get paid. I want my son to be a lawyer for the same reason. He doesn't get it. So what are the options?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the obvious is to buy back your own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick is finding the investors to back you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the banks will sell back to me because?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because nobody makes pink slop like you do Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banks just want a quick sale. They have no interest in running your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's jump on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to private equity firms, VCs, angels. The usual suspects. We'll find someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What doesn't break you, makes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Therapy. Don't charge me for that, will you? Rob? Don't let her charge me for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14   INT. PAPADOPOULOS & SONS FACTORY OFFICE. DAY 2 HARRY walks through his office and down to the factory fl where he overlooks a small army of oblivious Papadopoulos Sons employees processing taramasalata into containers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues. We see the front of the house. A standar removal truck is parked outside alongside the Mercedes an Bentley sports car - displaying (PAPA 1 and PAPA 2 number plates). Two removal men in white overalls and white glov (almost forensic looking) walk out the front door carryin large oil painting. A third man stands at the back of the waiting to receive goods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATIE walks down the stairs and we see removal men assess the valuables of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family, including MRS PARRINGTON, are in the kitchen. THEO is on his laptop. KATIE nervously files her nails. M PARRINGTON has made everyone a cup of tea. HARRY is readi newspaper. JAMES is reading a book. KATIE enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going through my things. It's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they darling. It's temporary. You'll get it all back. Two bank assessors RUPERT and NIGEL enter. RUPERT has a clipboard with items to be ticked off. NIGEL has a camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sarcastically) Oh. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Under his breath) Problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the... kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how long's this going to take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the day, I should think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are we allowed to keep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well. According to the asset sheet... let's see. Not very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little rats, with their little claws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is quite unnecessary Katie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may as well do this now. That's a nice computer. Oh, don't worry we're not going to, you know, take it... now. Anything interesting? THEO hisses at RUPERT like a snake with an aggressive fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stocks. Everyone's selling. I'm buying. Two, Four, Eight, 16, 32..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double your numbers quietly Theo and apologise or I'll confiscate that wretched computer for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no easy way of doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have impeccable taste, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We operate very strict guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have your range of Greek dips at home. Don't we Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was saying, we operate very strict guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. What is legally ours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the bank will let you keep ВЈ25,000 in cash. And you're each allowed ВЈ1,000 in personal items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Westwood Gold Label cost more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a beautiful dress. I couldn't resist looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispering) I'll sort something out for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispering) Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem like such a lovely family. We hate doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, so 25k cash. And 1000 in personal items. What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Well. One thing that came up in the meeting with HQ this morning. The fish and chip shop. The Three Brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What fish and chip shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That went years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the bank is unable to seize it as an asset because of its co- ownership with a... Spiros Papadopoulos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's his brother. But they haven't spoken in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is sitting at the dining room table watching S eat. No one else is eating and the table is set for one. dining room is spartan - less furniture/ no pictures. We some tea crates stuffed with tissue wrapped objects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so strange. Oh, James - more lemon son. JAMES passes SPIROS a small plate of quartered lemons. SP sticks his fork into one and squeezes juice over his chic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. This is so good Mrs P. In all the years, I never stopped thinking about you or your food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still so charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'm sitting there watching the telly and suddenly I see Papadopoulos & Sons. On the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy over leveraged himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this little Englezo. Hey! I'm your Uncle Spiros re. I'm your uncle, re manga! I'm going to eat him he's so cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't eat me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re gugluthi. He's just like his mother. A little Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because my Mummy was English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! I know re! I know. Ah. So! I'm watching the news and I'm thinking, what's my baby brother gone and done now? And just at that moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I'm thinking that thought, in the same split second, the phone rings. And it's him! I mean, it's gotta be some kind of quantum physics there, no? No? Insane. Insane. (To KATIE) Katie. You're so grown up. I can't believe this. You were like... just a girl. Dumpy and spoilt. Look at you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still a little spoilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nanny P!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And dumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so dumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, James. Sweet baby James. When you were three. How old was he? Three or four? We used to play fight. Remember? You loved to fight. Why, you broke my nose. Yeah! Fuck that hurt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. (To THEO) Duck! I said duck. (Quacking).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell your father. (Quaking) Harry. Thank you for phoning me. No, seriously. I'm so grateful. There's, you know... I know there's so much that we need to sort out, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we should be celebrating. Yeah? I don't drink anymore. Just so you know. But you don't have to be drunk to dance. That's what I say now. You don't have to be drunk to dance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic. So. Look. We're losing the house and well everything. It's only temporary. I'm in negotiations with a top corporate finance team to buy it back. But in the meantime, I need to free up some capital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you whatever I've got but you know, I don't have much money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your money Spiro. I want to sell the Three Brothers. We'll split it 50/50. I get enough money pay the rent, pay a few bills off and it's great for you because you get some cash to do whatever it is you want to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sell the Three Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it! I knew you'd be difficult. I knew it, I knew it, I knew it. You haven't changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't feel right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're loving this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Harry. I want to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see we're in the shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please. May I suggest we sleep on this? Before it gets out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is good advice Mrs P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry? Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. Time lapse of evening into night. 20   INT. PAPADOPOULOS MANSION - LIVING ROOM. DAY 5. HARRY, JAMES, KATIE, THEO and MRS PARRINGTON are sitting sofa. SPIROS addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep last night. Not a wink. Over and over, in my mind, I was trying to imagine selling the shop. Something here was saying, no, no. I want to help you. All of you. So I prayed for guidance. I asked the Universe. Please help me. Please help me help these people. And I must've fallen asleep not long after. A crazy sleep. And then this dream. Banayia mou. There was this, this music. The most incredible music. And you and me Harry. Running the shop. I woke with tears in my eyes and I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. What are you going on about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going to reopen the Three Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he talking about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. It's empty. Useless. We'd get nothing for it. But if we made the Three Brothers great again. Hey! That is our destiny! Okay. It needs work. Sure. But destiny need work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have. You. You have a better chance of getting through this if we increase the value of the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not opening a fish and chip shop, I'm Papadopoulos & Sons, I'm on supermarket shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. What would I tell my friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know, maybe the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mimicking) I don't know, maybe the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F.. f.. fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People! Hear me out. If we get it up and running again, we can sell it as a going concern instead of an empty shop. This deal you're working on could take ages. In the meantime, you're getting cash in and you're saving money because it's got two bedrooms. Eh? The Three Brothers is a goldmine. Used to be. Can be again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you become so practical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it fixed. I'm a handyman now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were a waiter Spiros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around too much booze Mrs P. I went travelling. Belgium, America, Brooklyn. I ended up managing a block of apartments in LA. I do painting, decorating, plumbing, electrics, everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who can fix things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. It's alright everyone. Don't panic. He's got a van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go look at the shop. Let me go and start working on it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of your mind. I know what you're up to. You want to make some money for yourself. That's fine. It's okay. It's okay. At least you're thinking smart these days. But don't involve us in all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given the current situation, I think it's worth consideration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm not opening a fish and chip shop. I'm not. I'm not! I'm not! I'm not! Not! Not! What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a private word? Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're behaving like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Parrington, with all due respect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the father of this family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather boil my own head than go back to a chip shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a terrible thing to say. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's unreliable Mrs P. He's irresponsible, he's a talker. He sings. He dances. He plays the bongo drums. He's a waiter. He'll drive us all mad and leave us broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems reformed to me. He doesn't drink anymore. I think he wants to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving back to a chip shop will destroy my children's confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing you behave like a spoilt brat will do that perfectly well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to smell of fish and chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children need a home. I don't give a fig for your bourgeois snobbery. Look at you. Everything has to be a drama with you Greeks. Show some gumption man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. We see the family get into Spiros' tatty white van SPIROS loads up some suitcases into the back. HARRY carri his businessman of the year award. JAMES has some plants. THEO has his laptop. KATIE has designer dress bags and sh On the side of the van we see "The Honest Handyman" with telephone number and the strapline, "If it's still broke. then we can't fix it. That's honesty!" The logo is a hamm with angel wings. The van pulls out of the drive. 23   EXT. THE THREE BROTHERS. DAY 6. The van pulls up in front of The Three Brothers Fish and Shop. The door is boarded up and covered in posters. We s the old sign, "The Three Brothers". The family, still sea in the van, stare out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we really going to live in that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to find something good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You'll love it! We're going to have a crazy time. We're going to fix this place up. I'm going to teach you how to do some Greek dancing, some singing. We'll fry some good fish. We'll laugh. Good times. SPIROS exits the van leaving the stunned family in silenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the road in the Bogazi Kebab Shop, HASSAN ALI and (his son) are standing in front of the shop. They watch a Papadopoulos family exit the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greeks are back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Greeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those Greeks. Hello my old friends. Mehmet. Find out what they're up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are inside The Three Brothers. We hear a jangle of key the door opens. The family walk in led by SPIROS. KATIE s carries her designer clothes bags and shoes, JAMES carrie plants, THEO his laptop and HARRY walks in last. It is an fashioned fish and chip shop that hasn't traded in 30 yea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. It looks much worse from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's actually a fish and chip shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is you spanner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy. Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? THEO picks out an old plaque-mounted stuffed fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr Charles. Our lucky fish. He helped us make the busiest chip shop in London. SPIROS takes in a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can smell the past. Your father and I. Young. The women. Young. Making good money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasting it. Gambling it. Losing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a crack den!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Let me show you the rest. We'll make it homely. Furniture, beds, TV. Come on. Let me show you. So... here is the prep room... The children follow SPIROS through the shop. HARRY is lef looking at the place, taking it all in. He takes out his and calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26   INT. MORTIMER ROLF & JONES - SOPHIE'S OFFICE. DA A phone rings at SOPHIE's office within Mortimer Rolf and HARRY's accountancy firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortimer Rolf and Jones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Could I speak to Rob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not at his desk. Can I take a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Harry Papadopoulos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi. It's Sophie. We met at your office, the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi. Any news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're lining up interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Well, I just need to know... I need to know if this is going to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest assured. We'll be driving the herd to Abilene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an old American, Mid-West expression. (Beat) Are you okay Mr. Papadopoulos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, all good. Just keep me informed please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. HARRY hangs up. ROB enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry Papadopoulos called. You should call him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go out, yeah. Let's celebrate. Let's find... I don't know... Let's find a... salsa club or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy just put another pig in da bag. Owch! A new instruction. Wallinghams. Big UK retail chain. Established. (Wallinghams jingle) Leave it... Leave it to Wallinghams... Comfortably, elegantly, reliably. Wallinghams. (Voice-over mode) Croydon, Greenwich, Enfield, Wimbledon and... Ding! Going into administration. Coming to little old moi for services rendered. (Tommy Cooper) Thank you. Oh thank you very much. God I love an economic downturn. Joking aside though. Five thousand laid off. Sad. Very, very sad. But dear sweet mother of God it was a shit business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Hallelujah! (He goes to exit) Six?

dialogues.speaker: INT DAY. THE THREE BROTHERS
dialogues.text: HARRY is on the verge of a panic attack. He slowly starts double numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, four, eight, sixteen... Two, four, eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, come at look at this giant mushroom I've found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPIROS, HARRY, JAMES and THEO walk up a steel staircase o Three Brother's roof terrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, yeah, yeah. Hey. Remember up here? We used to bring out the tables and chairs with the other Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ever happened to Soula, Pani and Stavro? I loved that crowd. Sometimes there'd be a poker game. Sometimes dancing. We had fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my Daddy dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I taught him. And your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mummy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Manga. This is the place where your Mummy and Daddy met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They talked all night. They danced. Yeah, there was a lot of dancing here. Hey. You want me to show you? How about it? SPIROS clicks his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiros please. It's not a holiday. Just show everyone around. HARRY exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (To THEO) I'll show you later. (To JAMES) You alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. No, I like the view. I might put some plants up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATIE is outside the shop, having a cigarette. We see Meh approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came all this way for a light? KATIE hands him a lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from the kebab shop across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. Silence. MEHMET's run out things to say. They both smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Dad wants me to spy on you. I don't think he like Greeks. (More silence) You want to go out sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mehmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Katie. (They shake hands) It's shit here, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pretty much. (Looking around) Yeah. Catch you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bye. MEHMET walks back to his shop. KATIE smiles. Music - Athi Athina by The Trio Attico . HARRY steps outside the shop. looks at KATIE who is still smoking. He stands there for moment looking a little lost. He gets into SPIROS' van an drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY drives to a cemetery. He parks the van and exits wi flowers. Harry walks through the cemetery. We see his wif Loving Memory of Elizabeth Papadopoulos 1962-2001 - Devot mother and wife'. He lays down his flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31   INT. MORTIMER ROLF & JONES - SOPHIE'S OFFICE. DA SOPHIE is at her desk. We see the same type of flowers in as Harry has laid down at the cemetery. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortimer, Rolf and Jones. Oh hi Dad. Yeah, I got them. They're beautiful. Thank you. Alright. Put her on. ROB enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispering) Right. Just a second. Hi mom. Thanks for the flowers, they're lovely. There was nothing wrong with New York. Yes, you can stay friends with Matt. And Bill and Susan. Mom, look, I've got a meeting. I don't know. Some meeting. Yeah, I promise, I will. I love you. Okay, bye. Bye. SOPHIE puts the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents. Is Matt your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. A bit of a tosser, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say tosser exactly. We just wanted different things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yada, yada, yada. Yeah, I hear ya. It's like me and my ex. She was keen and everything but I don't know, her forward thinking sort of killed the romance. Yeah. (Silence) It's good to have these little chats. Shouldn't always be about work. Society is so work obsessed. Tragic. Right. Back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32   INT. MORTIMER, ROLF & JONES - ROB'S OFFICE. DAY Seated around a conference table is ROB, SOPHIE and HARRY HARRY studies a spreadsheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some big names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pap & Sons is still a cash cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the potential deal structure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the pisser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd still be key to running the business, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money isn't cheap Harry. These guys will want at least 95% of the company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving me with nothing. I'd do the same thing. I'd be CEO of Papadopoulos & Sons. Get a salary. Get my house back. My children's future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It beats fish and chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be working for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be working for someone else. By the way, I'm not actually running a fish and chip shop. Just helping my brother relaunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Listen, there maybe another way. Came up in conversation with the Norske Velconan Bank. It'd be along the lines of a straight loan to buy back the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they lend me the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Let's ask them. Want me to look into it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, no choice. ROB's mobile alarm goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool. Got to go. Got an emergency with - get this - a high tech portable toilet company - that has literally gone down the tubes. (ROB holds up a flyer for the company) An internet ready, wireless, crapper with a waterproof keyboard and screen. For the love of God. Because taking a dump needed an overhaul. Still, somebody's got to bury them. Inomine patre, Spiritu, Sanctu... etc, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to love a downturn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laters. ROB exits. SOPHIE starts to pack her files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what you're currently doing with your brother sounds liberating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm liberating myself of my last 25 grand on a disused chip shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But its like a startup. Isn't that the most exciting phase of any venture? Taking a bit of a risk. Developing your products and your services. Learning about your market. Look, some of the largest companies on the planet never make a profit. Like a real profit. It's all accounting tricks and leveraged debt. What I'm trying to say is, does it matter if the business is a small one? As long as it makes a profit and the people who work there are happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing working in a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is only temporary. I got divorced recently. Came to London for a fresh start. I'm actually looking into setting up my own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry about that. About the divorce, I mean. Not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to ask. Can I come and visit your shop sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it's up and running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a chip shop. It's hot. On your feet all hours. Verbal abuse from customers on a Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't applying for a job Harry. Just wanted to stop by. SOPHIE exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO is in bed on his laptop. SPIROS knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. What are you doing little man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trading. I watch trends. Making trades based on patterns. I don't even look at the fundamentals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fundamentals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, capital employed, gearing ratios etc. Not even turnover or profit. It's short term, but I can spot a trend. I know what's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you can see the future? And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as the past. The pursuit of order from chaos. I'm done for today. SPIROS takes the laptop and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Theo, Theo, Theo. Guglouthi mou. Kali Nichta. Onira ylica. Sweet dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Spiros? You knew my Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She was... She was beautiful. And she was very kind to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had my Mummy sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very hard for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have made her laugh, Uncle Spiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come out with some classics. Real gems. Wasted on this family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! You are something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can hear everything.. KATIE and JAMES are at the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fall for him Spiros. He's a little tinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say the magic release poem!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, say it the magic release poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo Papadopoulos is a hippopotamus, who's always making such a fuss from his top to bottomus!!!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KATIE and JAMES tickle THEO who squeals with delight. SPI laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPIROS opens the door on the sparse living room. HARRY is neatly in silk pyjamas, in a sleeping bag on a camp bed. staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, your kids are something else. SPIROS undresses, taking off items of clothes until he is to his boxer shorts. SPIROS then gets out an icon of the Mary. He kisses it and then crosses himself three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm not too religious. I'm a lapsed Buddhist. I do everything a good Buddhist does except abstinence. SPIROS farts. Harry shuts his eyes and shakes his head in disgust. SPIROS then hands HARRY some ear plugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ear plugs. SPIROS gets into the sleeping bag and turns off the light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi re. This is a fantastic thing. Did you ever imagine, 30 years ago? Back here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember how excited we felt when we got this place? It feels like that again. Hey. My gut says... push Alaskan Pollock. Over Cod! What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should never have taken out that loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. We'll talk fish after we fix this place. (Singing) We'll talk fish after we fix this place. Katie's got some good thoughts. Says we should keep the old look. And she had some beautiful ideas about the uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then, you know. The potential yield of the Plaza. Papadopoulos Plaza. Fully developed with a thousand year lease. I would have kept the freehold. I'm telling you Spiro. It was good. I'd have been worth a fortune. Worth, I don't know. One billion five. One billion six. One billion six. Big numbers Spiro. Big, big numbers. SPIROS starts snoring. HARRY puts the ear plugs in and st out into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in front of the shop. SPIROS addresses a small gat of people who have turned up to help in the renovation. H a bottle of champagne. Alongside him, HARRY carries the b cleaning products. We see JAMES, KATIE, THEO and MRS PARR We see FAT LAKI, PHIL THE TILL, FATHER JIMMY, a Greek Ort priest and an assortment of Greek faces of various ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were children when we came to the UK with nothing. We start again. Fat Laki. The weight you lost is an inspiration. Phil The Till. You've helped many Greeks with your tax friendly till machines. Eh, only two things are certain in life - death and taxes. Unless you're Greek. Then it's only death! (The crowd cheer). Nikos, Kyriaco, Androniki, Loula, Uncle Panikos, Aphrodite, Maria and of course, Father Jimmy. Thank you. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Father Jimmy get done for selling illegal copies of Rambo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got three liquor stores in Palmers Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always hated me. HARRY now addresses the small crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People. Hello. Sorry. Hi. I just want you to know this is a temporary situation for the family. I'm currently in negotiations with a top corporate finance team about re- acquiring the assets of Papadopoulos & Sons. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had some sort of breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tragic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, music. SPIROS nods towards JAMES who pushes a button on a his do MP3 player. Greek music - Oba, Oba Ta Bouzoukia by the De Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I officially announce the renovation of the Three Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to do that after you launch something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with convention. SPIROS smashes the bottle on the floor and rallies the as party who cheer 'bravo' and clap.

dialogues.speaker: INT/ EXT. THE THREE BROTHERS
dialogues.text: Montage to the same music. MRS PARRINGTON picks up a tray with teas and we follow her through the shop. She stops s that people can take a mug and we see her continue her journey - all the way through the shop to outside, where see HARRY sitting alone in the van. He's not part of the activity. We see scrubbing, cleaning, fixing. Boards are taken down. Inside we see people painting and the fish fr cleaned. We see product displays go up. We see SPIROS wit manic and crazy enthusiasm. JAMES and KATIE messing aroun Finally, we see FATHER JIMMY splashing holy water, saying prayer and making the sign of the cross over the fish fry range while others stand and watch the ceremony with resp

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He splashes water on those assembled. They wince as the h water hits them. The music fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAT LAKI is tasting strips of kebab meat. He is making no he does so, marking for texture, flavour etc. Around him SPIROS, MRS PARRINGTON, JAMES, KATIE, THEO and HARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hade re Laki. Tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entaxi. Don't rush me. Its been a long time since I had meat like this. FAT LAKI takes another bite and looks upwards as he chews

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's assessing the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E belame mas (He's driving us crazy).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a reason Hassan's still in business. Texture, very good. Way above average. Meat content. High. Mechanically recovered cheap rubbish? You wish. This is a quality donner, nicely cooked with all the right combination of herbs. It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't mean we can't take them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not saying we can't. MEHMET walks into the shop and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of Greeks. Katie grabs her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? We're going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too late. KATIE exits with MEHMET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she is 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make a better product at a cheaper price with larger portions. We'll lose money on the kebabs in the short term, put Turks out of business within a year, make our margins on the fish and when the rest of this crummy street has packed up we'll raise our prices and cut our portion sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrepreneur has spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's temporary, but as long as we're here we'll do some business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of the finished gleaming shop at night. hear the sound of a sizzling frying pan. We hear the crac an egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An egg being broken over chips and fish scraps. SPIROS is cooking. HARRY and JAMES are sitting at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when he was a little boy, he'd come home from school and sit there - just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the third b.. brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael. He died in the fire. With our parents, your grandparents, in Cyprus. In the war between the Greeks and Turks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you both escape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiros climbed down and Michael who was... six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropped me down. I was just a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught him. But Michael... He. I told Mihalis to jump. But he... he ran right back into the house. We'll never know why. One night and everything changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably wanted to save his Mum and Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I never thought about that. You could be right. Yeah. You are a wise boy James. Your soul is old. Tell me. This has always been a big question for me. For many years. Do you think... do you think... I could've done something else? For Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You were holding a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how old were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you were only a boy. Like Theo. HARRY has stopped eating. He looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H? Hello? What's wrong with him? Hey. Don't worry. It's temporary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. HARRY exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY is lying on top of his camp bed. JAMES knocks and enters with a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was only nine. I never thought about how young he was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you this. Tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. Come here. Sit down. I've let you and your brother and your sister down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a promise to your mother that I'd take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is humiliating for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, we'll get through this. Like... I don't know. Like King Lear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, King Lear loses everything. Absolutely everything and he finds himself in the middle of this storm with nothing and all his kids h.. h.. hate him. They think he's a prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. He dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it has to end like that because its a tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your plants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can grow new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you bring more with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to get in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a sweet boy. You get that from your mother. Your stammer is getting better. You know what? I'm going to go and get your plants. Now. From the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get your plants. Like King Lear. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er. Yeah. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY is back at the old house. There is an 'Auction' sig the entrance. We see a skip. We see him peering in throug window. He walks over to the skip and looks in. He climbs Inside the skip among old cardboard boxes, a broken chair finds a selection of plants - some of them in pots. He pi up, the one with the distinctive Union Jack pot, and brus leaves. We then see him walk off with a box of plants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPIROS, JAMES, KATIE and THEO are making batter. It is la They are all in their pyjamas. We see beer cans, a vodka bottle and bags of flour. The radio plays Greek music. HA enters carrying a cardboard box of plants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're making b.. batter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Spiros' special mix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I could find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said they could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the holidays. THEO gets upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Spiros said I could make beer and vodka batter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You can stay up. It's the holidays. Tomorrow, we'll look through the newspapers and pick out some stocks. How does that grab you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natural resources is a good buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait. Show us your frying skills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was telling them how you were born with a timer in your head. How you fried to perfection every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Dad, show us how to fillet a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes H. Come on. Show us. Show us. Show us! Show us! The children join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us! Show us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should really be thinking about bed, all of you. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bed? HARRY exits. SPIROS tastes his batter and is happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY stares at himself in the mirror. He can hear muffle laughter from the rest of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY is seated. He is fiddling with his suit and tie. He JAMES pushing a wheelbarrow with plants, smoking what loo a joint. HARRY shakes his head. SPIROS gets in the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, that's it. Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: City. Get a loan. Get the business back, get the house back. Does this suit look alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't. I don't know. It doesn't fit. As they are about to set off HARRY sees KATIE and MEHMET kissing in the wing mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. They're kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Kids. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're smoking. They're hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they? Are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they screwing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They're just kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get out of this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He's a sweet guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! The family is in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're overreacting Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thought of her pregnant. In a kebab shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry. Don't worry about Katie. She can look after herself. Spiros starts the van. We see it pull away. Music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see the van driving through London before it pulls an industrial estate and come to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPIROS turns off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Katie? Is she pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. Have you've got cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. SPIROS pulls out eight or nine A4 pages of hand written n He takes out his reading glasses. Reading the piece of pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just bear with me. So. Here goes. After years of abuse on my behalf and unacceptable behavior, I reached a moment of clarity - actually this was two years ago. (Reading) I'd like to apologise for the hurt I've caused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading) There were aspects of my behaviour which were unacceptable. This includes, and is not limited to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been carrying this. Well, if you don't want to hear we can do it later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Now is fine. Now is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just. (Reading note paper and turning over pages) Oxi. Oxi. Skip that. (Beat) I have abused your generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with that statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we were children and got to London I looked after you. Got you ready for school. Made you do your homework. I taught you to cook, ride a bike, speak Greek. Dance. (Beat) Why don't you speak Greek re?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were reading your list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fought with Stephen Klein, when he accused you of stealing his orthopedic shoe. Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't steal the shoe. Are you going to read all of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did it go wrong with us Spiro? We may as well get to it. Why did you turn against me after I left the shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never turned against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it felt like. Spiros puts the notes down. He takes off his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was jealous of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers get jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were more than a brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were my life and then you left. Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I set up the business. I wasn't going to stay in the shop. You could've come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, you were so fast. You were like a plane, like a supersonic jet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I gave you everything you wanted. Did I ever once turn you down? In all the years after I left the business. Did I? And after it went bust? But it was never enough. Every week something new. Writing a cheque to... I don't know. You had some weird friends. Who was that bloke with the pin head? Kept turning up at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of my friends anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then drunk at Elizabeth's funeral? And your big 'tell it as it is' speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was it for me. For us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right to cut me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never had a bad word for you Elizabeth. Always forgave you. And she made me forgive you. Every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did. I always had a way back when she was with us. Elizabeth was so good to me. She was our world. She was our world. Harry is chocked and is trying to hold it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay H.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get to this meeting. It's an important meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay to miss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man. (Silence) Just give me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Spiros' solitary van parked up in ghostly industri estate. The van eventually starts and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48   INT. MORTIMER, ROLF & JONES - BOARD ROOM. DAY 10 SOPHIE, ROB, HARRY and LARS - a Scandinavian banker - are sitting round the boardroom table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the help of Lars and the Norske Velconan Bank, we aim to buy Pap and Sons back from the receivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, I have to say Harry that I believe there is an intuitive bond between the Greek and the Nordic peoples, yah? And so, maybe the very first vikings were descended from Ancient Greeks, somewhere in the deep mists of time. And so it's so... so Wagnerian, yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should point out the new approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To buy Papadopoulos & Sons but divest the food manufacturing side of the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divest the food manufacturing? What else is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell off the food but keep the property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papadopoulos Plaza. It's going to be worth a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an asset breakup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tusk. Tusk, yah? Makes us sound like barbarians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the new loan, you'd buy back your old assets and then sell off the brands in the Pap & Sons stable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. And you know how to squeeze the value Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a break up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. I know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitta bread, the cakes get sold to a bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The halloumi and feta to a dairy company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love your halloumi! Grilled. It's... (Kisses air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sell off value of these brands will exceed the new loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my bank will get its money back faster than you can say 'knife'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars wants 50% of the Plaza development. Which is what will remain after the debts have been settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you get 50% of the development for free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, yeah. But you get 50% of the same development yah, also for free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my food business back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy,   guys, guys. Reality check. Harry. It's   not going to happen. Okay? The best   you can hope for is to work with Lars   here and save something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So. Yah. I need to take this to the board. Take two, three months. But pish, yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems criminal to buy the business back only to break it up. As an aside to SOPHIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just point out that you are skating. Figuratively speaking. On thin fucking ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever the bank wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Harry, we are going to take this to the hoop, yah? Three points! Yah? Three points!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49   INT. MORTIMER, RALF & JONES - CORRIDOR. DAY 10. HARRY and SOPHIE are walking towards the lifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking out a loan to pay off a loan? So you can remortgage a property? It's got nothing to do with business. It's got nothing to do with making stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get my life back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You get a loan for some land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My children get their lives back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This isn't very professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you give all your clients a hard time Sophie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just the interesting ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just want to talk about the shop and make sure my brother's got the right plan before I go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's grab a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOPHIE and HARRY are strolling along London's South Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's 30% on materials. The fish, the potatoes, the packaging etc. Would you include energy? Light, heat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But not rent because we already own the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. And 30% on labour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's 30/30/30. Classic restaurant model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your weaknesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The price of fish can vary. Dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you vary the menu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to complicate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to be complicated Harry. (Beat) What are your fears?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fears? Oh. Just that it just won't work out. That fish and chips has maybe had its day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Hang on a second. (They stop) Fish and chips is a British classic. It's much more than just a quick meaningless experience. It's something to be savoured. Just think of the soft, white, cod flakes, gently falling away as your fork pierces the hard, crunchy shell of the golden batter. The rich smells of a fryer's delight. The tangy smack of salt and vinegar on your lips. Hell yeah. I'd pay for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (HARRY and SOPHIE exchange glances. They hold a look) We should talk about... We should talk about accounting packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We should We see HARRY and SOPHIE walk down South Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEHMET and KATIE are kissing on a bridge. KATIE breaks aw and stares into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time last year I was in Malibu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a nightclub. It's America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Look. The shop's where I'm from but it's not where I'm going to end up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Dad must've said that to my Mum once. Maybe even on this bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Look where he ended up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's your plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
